item.title: Intown Jewish Education Conversation
item.description:
Marcus Hillel Center at Emory: Arogeti Chapel
Sunday, October 23, 2011, 7 – 9pm

Do you have a young family and live in Intown Atlanta? What do YOU want for your child's Jewish education?

Whether yours are infants or have graduated high school, we want to hear your thoughts!

Light snacks and wine.
Please invite your friends and RSVP to ana@jewishkidsgroups.com

Hosted by Ana Fuchs and Linda Brenner.

item.title: Lunch & Learn: Discussions on Jewish Philosophy & Theology
item.description:
Marcus Hillel Center - Cohen Jewish Resource Center
Tuesday, October 25, 2011, 12 – 1pm

God, Torah & Israel: Discussions on Jewish Philosophy & Theology

Lunch & Learn every other Tuesday from noon to 1 PM beginning September 13, 2011. Explore BIG ideas in Judaism drawing on various thinkers and texts throughout Jewish history. Drop in for lunch, stimulating learning and open discussion on a wide range of topics with Rabbi Elana Zelony of Congregation Shearith Israel. Please arrive early to order lunch, which is available for sale at Goodfriend's Grill in the Marcus Hillel Center. Parking is available at the 1525 Clinic on North Gatewood Road.

item.title: ICC Regional Field Training
item.description:
Sunday, October 30, 12pm – Monday, October 31, 2011, 4pm

The Israel on Campus Coalition field training provides professionals with the skills, education and confidence to help students deal with Israel’s detractors on campus and give them tools to make effective positive campus change for Israel. Professionals will end this training with a playbook, evaluation and planning tools, a pro-active campus action plan, and more confidence related to dealing with Israel on campus.

Please register here: israelcc.org…

More info: israelcc.org…

item.title: Performance: Creativity Conversation with Matt Haimovitz, cello
item.description:
Marcus Hillel Center
Thursday, November 3, 2011, 6 – 7:30pm

Renowned as a musical pioneer, cellist Matt Haimovitz has inspired classical music lovers and countless new listeners by bringing his artistry to concert halls and clubs, outdoor festivals and intimate coffee houses, any place where passionate music can be heard. Through his visionary approach he brings a fresh ear to familiar repertoire and champions new music. Haimovitz is re-defining what it means to be an artist for the 21st century. In this program Haimovitz will be playing two pieces by Jewish composers and discussing their themes with Music Department Chair Kevin Karnes and Religion professor David Blumenthal.

Presented by the Emory Center for Creativity & the Arts; the David Goldwasser Series in Religion and the Arts; Coca-Cola Artist in Residence.

Reception presented by Hillel at Emory University to follow.

More info: www.arts.emory.edu

item.title: Gil Hoffman: "Peace, Politics, and Plutonium: an insider's look at the quest for security, democracy & peace in the Middle East"
item.description:
MHC: Segal Social Hall
Monday, November 7, 2011, 8:30 – 9:30pm

Gil Hoffman is the chief political correspondent and analyst for The Jerusalem Post. Well-connected to Israeli and Palestinian leaders, Hoffman has interviewed every major figure across the Israeli political spectrum, has been interviewed by top media on six continents and is a regular analyst on CNN, Al-Jazeera and other news outlets.

Called "The most optimistic man in Israel" by Israel Television, Hoffman's writing and TV appearances provide a behind the scenes look at the intrigue and humor in the Israeli political arena.

Hoffman, who was raised in Chicago, graduated Magna Cum Laude from Northwestern University's School of Journalism and wrote for the Miami Herald and Arizona Republic before moving to Israel. A reserve soldier in the IDF's Spokesman's Unit, he has lectured in seven countries and 36 US states. He lives in Jerusalem with his wife, and two children.

An open session of Maimonides. Co-Sponsored by Meor and Hillel at Emory.
item.xCal:summary: Gil Hoffman: "Peace, Politics, and Plutonium: an insider's look at the quest for security, democracy & peace in the Middle East"

Called "The most optimistic man in Israel" by Israel Television, Hoffman's writing and TV appearances provide a behind the scenes look at the intrigue and humor in the Israeli political arena.

item.title: MJCCA Book Festival Event feat. Rabbi Andrea Myers
item.description:
Sunday, November 13, 2011, 10am – 12pm

Rabbi Andrea Myers, The Choosing
A Rabbi's Journey from Silent Nights to High Holy Days

A young Lutheran girl grows up on Long Island, New York. She aspires to be a doctor, and is on the fast track to marriage and the conventional happily-ever-after. But, as the Yiddish saying goes, "Man plans, and God laughs." Meet Andrea Myers, whose coming-of-age at Brandeis, conversion to Judaism, and awakening sexual identity make for a rich and well-timed life in the rabbinate. In The Choosing, Myers fuses heartwarming anecdotes with rabbinic insights and generous dollops of humor to describe what it means to survive and flourish on your own terms. Portioned around the cycle of the Jewish year, with stories connected to each of the holidays, Myers draws on her unique path to the rabbinate-- leaving behind her Christian upbringing, coming out as a lesbian, discovering Judaism in college, moving to Israel, converting, and returning to New York to become a rabbi, partner, and parent.


More information is available here:
www.atlantajcc.org…

More info: www.atlantajcc.org…
item.xCal:summary: MJCCA Book Festival Event feat. Rabbi Andrea Myers

A young Lutheran girl grows up on Long Island, New York. She aspires to be a doctor, and is on the fast track to marriage and the conventional happily-ever-after. But, as the Yiddish saying goes, "Man plans, and God laughs." Meet Andrea Myers, whose coming-of-age at Brandeis, conversion to Judaism, and awakening sexual identity make for a rich and well-timed life in the rabbinate. In The Choosing, Myers fuses heartwarming anecdotes with rabbinic insights and generous dollops of humor to describe what it means to survive and flourish on your own terms. Portioned around the cycle of the Jewish year, with stories connected to each of the holidays, Myers draws on her unique path to the rabbinate-- leaving behind her Christian upbringing, coming out as a lesbian, discovering Judaism in college, moving to Israel, converting, and returning to New York to become a rabbi, partner, and parent.

Tuesday, November 22, 2011, 12 – 1pm

God, Torah & Israel: Discussions on Jewish Philosophy & Theology

Lunch & Learn every other Tuesday from noon to 1 PM beginning September 13, 2011. Explore BIG ideas in Judaism drawing on various thinkers and texts throughout Jewish history. Drop in for lunch, stimulating learning and open discussion on a wide range of topics with Rabbi Elana Zelony of Congregation Shearith Israel. Please arrive early to order lunch, which is available for sale at Goodfriend's Grill in the Marcus Hillel Center. Parking is available at the 1525 Clinic on North Gatewood Road.
